Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Quantifying the effect of centralization on the resilience of the regional healthcare system in the 2010-11 Canterbury earthquake sequence
Award.AbstractNarration:
Healthcare systems have been identified worldwide as critical infrastructure that must remain functional for communities to effectively respond to disasters such as earthquakes. Much disaster resilience research has assumed that system-wide functionality can be predicted from the performance of independent hospitals. Healthcare, however, functions as a networked system of providers and facilities, rather than a set of independent entities. Therefore, to better understand healthcare delivery after a disaster, it is important to capture the contributions and interactions of all parts of the system. This study will apply engineering techniques for analyzing complex systems to a resilience-based framework in order to characterize healthcare at a system level. This framework will be used to determine the effect of centralization on overall healthcare system performance following seismic events. The Canterbury region, which sustained severe damage in the 2010-2011 Canterbury Earthquake Sequence, provides a unique opportunity to study a highly centralized healthcare system recovering from a series of devastating earthquakes. This work will be performed in collaboration with Dr. Sonia Giovinazzi and the University of Canterbury in New Zealand.

The healthcare system will be characterized through interviews with administrators, engineers, and healthcare providers. Emphasis will be placed on how organizations within the system allocate resources needed to create surge capacity, such as space (including infrastructure), staff, and supplies. This study will also examine how resource allocation changed after the earthquakes. Fault-tree analysis will be applied to connect the high-level functionality of the healthcare system (e.g., ability to provide surgery) with base-level performance of resources (e.g. loss of sewage) under four conditions: decentralized pre-earthquake, centralized pre-earthquake, decentralized post-earthquake, and centralized post-earthquake. Resilience under each condition will be calculated for scenario events using functions-based resilience metrics developed for this study. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Royal Society of New Zealand.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Healthcare has been identified worldwide as critical infrastructure that must be kept functional for communities to effectively respond to disasters such as earthquakes. Previous research has often assumed that system-wide functionality can be predicted from the performance of independent hospitals. Healthcare, however, functions as a networked system of providers and facilities, rather than a set of independent entities. Therefore, to better understand healthcare delivery after a disaster, it is important to capture the contributions and interactions of all parts of the system. It is also important to consider that disasters like earthquakes not only create increased demand for medical services; they often damage the resources needed to provide healthcare, such as space, staff, and supplies. This project applied engineering techniques for data collection and analysis of complex systems to create a resilience-based framework for characterizing the performance of healthcare at a system level. This framework was used create a complete model of an existing healthcare system, which can be used to simulate and quantify the performance of that healthcare system after seismic events. The Canterbury region of New Zealand, which sustained severe damage in the 2010-2011 Canterbury Earthquake Sequence, provided a unique opportunity to study a highly centralized healthcare system recovering from a series of devastating earthquakes.

 

In order to collect the data needed to characterize the system, a new survey tool was created, the Healthcare Resilience Survey. The tool consisted of three sections, each of which was designed to be completed in one hour. Section one captured the baseline state of a healthcare facility in terms of the services it offered, staffing, supplies, and the building and infrastructure. Section two recorded the resource needs for individual services. Section three examined the role of a central healthcare authority in providing care. The survey tool was used in series of interviews conducted with approximately 50 administrators, engineers, and healthcare providers from 16 different healthcare organizations.

 

The data collected through these interviews was then used to create a two-part model of the healthcare system. In the first part, fault-tree analysis was applied to each facility in the healthcare system to connect the high-level functionality of healthcare services (e.g., ability to provide surgery) with base-level performance of resources (e.g. loss of sewage). In the second part, the individual facilities were connected through a network model of the healthcare system, where each node was one of the facilities or organizations in the system. The arcs which connected the nodes represented the agreements between different organizations to share resources and transfer patients. The combined two part model will be used to simulate and quantify the performance of the system after seismic events. This work was performed in collaboration with Dr. Sonia Giovinazzi at the University of Canterbury in New Zealand and Dr. Judith Mitrani-Reiser at Johns Hopkins University in the United States.
